linkTarget.anchoringText: While Soi remains constant as it depicts the initial reservoir condition, the Sor values is dynamic. Sor can decrease with good reservoir practice and enhanced recovery mechanism thus implying that Sor is a controllable parameter. Sor exist because of the inability of the viscous force and/or the gravity forces to completely overcome the capillary forces. The relationship between the three forces is expressed by the Capillary and Bond numbers expressed in figure 1 below.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Mathematical expressions for Capillary & Bond Numbers ( Rifaat Al-Mjeni, 2011)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Mathematical expressions for Capillary & Bond Numbers ( Rifaat Al-Mjeni, 2011 )

linkTarget.bib:
Al-Mjeni, (2011)
Rifaat Al-Mjeni : "Has the time come for EOR?" Schlumberger Oil Field Review (2011), 21 .

linkTarget.anchoringText: Areal sweep efficiency is defined as the fraction of the total area of the oil reservoir that has been contacted by water. It is usually delineated as EA. The vertical sweep efficiency (delineated as EV) on the other hand is the fraction of the reservoir thickness contacted by water. EA and EV are better depicted as shown in figure 2 below.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: illustration of areal and vertical sweep efficiency (Modified after "Analyzing water flood Patterns 1" - www.unimasr.net/ums/…/UniMasr.com_6acf945fd1e651674f0b57dbc3beabe5.pdf)

formatted-caption.caption-text: illustration of areal and vertical sweep efficiency (Modified after "Analyzing water flood Patterns 1" - www.unimasr.net/ums/…/UniMasr.com_6acf945fd1e651674f0b57dbc3beabe5.pdf)

linkTarget.anchoringText: This is because optimal well coverage that considers the connectivity of the hydrocarbon fluid increases the EA and EC to values as high as 100% (See Appendix 1 & 6). At the other end, optimal well completion (perforation interval, completion type, ease of future access for well interventions etc) greatly impacts the EV.

image-wrap.label: Appendix 1
image-wrap.caption: Top Structure map for EPUK F0000A Reservoir

formatted-caption.caption-text: Top Structure map for EPUK F0000A Reservoir

linkTarget.anchoringText: The reservoir has good well coverage with a total of 9 wells completed on it (see Appendix 1 & 2). This practice encourages a good EA. Perforations from most of the wells have been optimally placed carefully considering sand quality and water contact (see Appendix 9). In cases where perforations were not crestal (well 6 and well 10), nearby wells with shallower perforations (well 5 and 32) are sufficient to recover any attic oil in the affected well.

image-wrap.label: Appendix 2
image-wrap.caption: Fluid Distribution Plot for EPUK F0000A Reservoir

formatted-caption.caption-text: Fluid Distribution Plot for EPUK F0000A Reservoir

linkTarget.anchoringText: Although no BHP was acquired during the short period of production, there are two strong indications of good aquifer support. Firstly, the well when closed-in (for flowline failure- see Appendix 3) was still producing at a BSW of 78 %. This is indicative of a good aquifer support. Secondly pressure depletion analysis of all other produced/producing reservoirs in the field indicates < 10 % pressure depletion. These outcomes indicate a very high Ee.

image-wrap.caption: Apendix 3 Reservoir Performance plot for EPUK F0000A reservoir

formatted-caption.caption-text: Apendix 3 Reservoir Performance plot for EPUK F0000A reservoir

linkTarget.anchoringText: Forty-Nine (49) Bottom Hole Pressures (BHPs) have been acquired over the 40-year period of production from all the wells. These pressures, acquired from the different wells, when plotted over time (see Appendix 4) clearly indicate rapid pressure equilibration and fluid connectivity. This dynamic observation strongly supports the initial static observation on reservoir connectivity strongly indicting a very high EC.

image-wrap.label: Appendix 4
image-wrap.caption: Pressure & Liquid withdrawal Rate Vs Time plot for EPUK F0000A Reservoir

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pressure & Liquid withdrawal Rate Vs Time plot for EPUK F0000A Reservoir

linkTarget.anchoringText: The implication of this is that oil can be produced even at very high BSW which indeed was the case (see Appendix 4). supporting a high Ee. Although ED is not within control, as stated earlier under the primary recovery phase, for EPUK F0000A a high ED was observed. An approximate quantitative analysis of the RST acquired in 2013 from one of the flushed wells (see Appendix 5) indicate remaining oil saturation between 15 – 20%. This result implies that an ED estimate of 76 – 82 % is possibly at play.

image-wrap.label: Appendix 5
image-wrap.caption: Residual saturation log from one of the completed wells (well 18) in EPUK F0000A reservoir.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Residual saturation log from one of the completed wells (well 18) in EPUK F0000A reservoir.

linkTarget.anchoringText: This is because optimal well coverage that considers the connectivity of the hydrocarbon fluid increases the EA and EC to values as high as 100% (See Appendix 1 & 6). At the other end, optimal well completion (perforation interval, completion type, ease of future access for well interventions etc) greatly impacts the EV.

image-wrap.label: Appendix 6
image-wrap.caption: Top Structure map for Saguro D4000X Reservoir

formatted-caption.caption-text: Top Structure map for Saguro D4000X Reservoir

linkTarget.anchoringText: The reservoir has good well coverage with a total of 4 wells completed on it (Appendix Apendix 6 & 7). This practice encourages a good EA. Perforations from most of the wells have been optimally placed carefully considering sand quality, water contact and the gas contact (see Appendix 7). Production from the reservoir began in 1972 and has continued to date. Production has been largely well managed as the general performance diagnosis of the wells indicates that the overall production philosophy over time was based on good wells and reservoir management practice. The implication of this practice is a good EV.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The reservoir has good well coverage with a total of 9 wells completed on it (see Appendix 1 & 2). This practice encourages a good EA. Perforations from most of the wells have been optimally placed carefully considering sand quality and water contact (see Appendix 9). In cases where perforations were not crestal (well 6 and well 10), nearby wells with shallower perforations (well 5 and 32) are sufficient to recover any attic oil in the affected well.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pressure & Liquid withdrawal Rate Vs Time plot for Saguro D4000X Reservoir

linkTarget.anchoringText: The case of TANA F8000N reservoir presents a very unique and interesting case. The reservoir is a small one with was a STOIIP of ~ 13 MMstb. Consequently, it was only developed with 1 well which was located close to the crest of the structure (Appendix 10 & 11). Production was brief starting in 20001 and ending in 2004 (about 4 years- see production profile in Appendix 1). The well was horizontal (with a horizontal leg of ~1650 ft) and as such had a good area contact with the oil. This definitely limited coning possibility thus encouraging both EA and EV.

image-wrap.label: Appendix 10
image-wrap.caption: Top structure Map for TANA F8000N Reservoir

formatted-caption.caption-text: Top structure Map for TANA F8000N Reservoir

linkTarget.anchoringText: The case of TANA F8000N reservoir presents a very unique and interesting case. The reservoir is a small one with was a STOIIP of ~ 13 MMstb. Consequently, it was only developed with 1 well which was located close to the crest of the structure (Appendix 10 & 11). Production was brief starting in 20001 and ending in 2004 (about 4 years- see production profile in Appendix 1). The well was horizontal (with a horizontal leg of ~1650 ft) and as such had a good area contact with the oil. This definitely limited coning possibility thus encouraging both EA and EV.

image-wrap.label: Appendix 11
image-wrap.caption: Fluid Distribution Plot for TANA F8000N Reservoir

formatted-caption.caption-text: Fluid Distribution Plot for TANA F8000N Reservoir

image-wrap.label: Appendix 12
image-wrap.caption: Production Performance Plot for TANA F8000N Reservoir

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production Performance Plot for TANA F8000N Reservoir

linkTarget.anchoringText: Over 26 BHPs have been acquired over the past 44 years of production. The pressure depletion analysis indicates a depletion of 4 % (see Appendix 9) over this period indicating a strong water drive. This is further buttressed by the BSW seen from the producing/produced wells (> 80 %). An example for one of the flushed wells is shown in Appendix 13. These positive attributes invariably lead to a high Ee. The intra reservoir faults picked by the acquired seismic is not extensive which establishes fluid continuity and connectivity (see Appendix 6).

image-wrap.label: Appendix 13
image-wrap.caption: Depth Vs STOIIP Plot for TANA F8000N Reservoir

formatted-caption.caption-text: Depth Vs STOIIP Plot for TANA F8000N Reservoir
